{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3549878,"name":"Alex","username":"AlexChestnut","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/alexchestnut/{size}/247683_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-06T22:27:21.796Z","cooked":"

Hello everybody, my team was wondering how they should go about aligning to each side of a reef only using one limelight.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":3,"updated_at":"2025-03-06T22:27:21.796Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":28,"reads":94,"readers_count":93,"score":173.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":494558,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-use-lime-light-to-align-to-the-reef","display_username":"Alex","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46359,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-use-lime-light-to-align-to-the-reef/494558/1","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3549913,"name":"Leo & Mali","username":"SeansCoolerFriend","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/seanscoolerfriend/{size}/232971_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-06T22:56:10.987Z","cooked":"

Hi there! Limelight on the fly path generation is what we are utilizing this year.

1.) So, essentially, on-the-fly path generation will create a spline curve that will also rotate the robot (because it can estimate current robot pose), meaning you don’t actually have to adjust for angle.

2.) We are using a calculation we found on the limelight documentation page in order to generate our paths to the reef. (here it is: Estimating Distance | Limelight Documentation)

To use the calculation, you will need to mount your limelight in a position where it will not move, and then record some constants like your limelight’s height above the ground and angle from the ground, this image is helpful if you want to get an idea of what those constants are.

Just to let you know, we are using CTRE generated swerve code for krakens, so our code may look different from yours but if you’d like to look at our limelight subsystem, it should be pretty similar to what you are trying to achieve here.

here’s our github:

github.com

GitHub - warroboticss/Fluke2025: our super cool! absolute fluke!

our super cool! absolute fluke!

Good luck, and let me know if you have any questions!
(we are using swerve btw, this won’t really work for anything else)
